sn52.2:4.2: Then as Anuruddha was in private solitude this thought came to his mind:
sn52.2:4.3: “Whoever has missed out on these four kinds of mindfulness meditation has missed out on the noble path to the complete ending of suffering.
sn52.2:4.4: Whoever has undertaken these four kinds of mindfulness meditation has undertaken the noble path to the complete ending of suffering.”
sn52.2:5.1: Then Venerable Mahāmoggallāna knew what Venerable Anuruddha was thinking.
sn52.2:5.2: As easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm,
sn52.2:5.4: he reappeared in front of Anuruddha,
sn52.2:6.2: “Reverend Anuruddha, how do you define the undertaking of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation by a mendicant?”
sn52.2:7.1: “Reverend, it’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body internally, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn52.2:7.2: They meditate observing an aspect of the body externally …
sn52.2:7.3: internally and externally, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn52.2:8.1: They meditate by observing an aspect of feelings internally …
sn52.2:9.1: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind internally …
sn52.2:10.1: They meditate observing an aspect of principles internally …
sn52.2:10.3: internally and externally, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn52.2:10.4: That’s how to define the undertaking of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation by a mendicant.”
